thread.title: Mitchell Marsh has ability to make it to the very top, says mentor
thread.title_full: Mitchell Marsh has ability to make it to the very top, says mentor | The Advertiser

author: GREG BUCKLE
title: Mitchell Marsh has ability to make it to the very top, says mentor
text:
MITCHELL Marsh’s raw figures as a Test player don’t exactly scream he’s the next Jacques Kallis.
But it’s his raw ability that fuels optimism among Australia’s selectors that the all-rounder who averages 28.2 can be a long-term success as a top-six batsman.
After scoring 48 runs at an average of 12 in three Ashes Tests in July and August, the West Australian hit 64 and 40 not out in the one-day series against England and took eight wickets at 24.1.
“There’s no question of his ability,” Marsh’s mentor and former Western Australia and Sri Lanka coach Tom Moody told the Herald Sun this week.
“Everyone recognises he has that potential. He’s still just 23.
“What he needs to do is present himself as a genuine batsman, an all-rounder who’s capable of scoring hundreds.
“He had a disjointed Ashes with his selection coming in and out of the side and I don’t think that helps.”
Moody stresses it’s crucial that Marsh puts some big scores on the board, starting with next month’s three-Test series against New Zealand.
“It doesn’t mean that he has to go out there and smash hundreds in the first or second Test match, but showing signs he is emerging as that ideal all-rounder in that top six,” former Test all-rounder Moody said.

Wiser heads still have plenty of faith in Marsh’s ability. Source: Getty Images
Moody played alongside Marsh’s father Geoff in Australia’s 1987 World Cup-winning campaign. He says he has known Mitchell Marsh “since day dot”.
“I’ve worked closely with Mitch over the last couple of years as a friend and as I suppose a mentor for him as he’s charting those choppy waters,” Moody said.
One of Marsh’s challenges is dealing with the weight of expectation, not only as an emerging player but as a possible future Test skipper as predicted by then-Australia captain Michael Clarke 12 months ago.
“What Michael Clarke is saying there is that there’s more to Mitch than an exciting all-rounder,” Moody said.
“He has genuine leadership qualities.”
Moody says the pressure on Marsh “comes with the territory”.
Selectors are willing to show patience as Marsh develops. Source: Getty Images
“Glenn Maxwell is dealing with the same issues,” Moody said.
“It takes time for those talented players to get the consistency of performance together. Given patience, that more often than not pays off over the long term.
“We’ve seen that historically with Australian players, whether it’s Steve Waugh or the current Australian captain Steve Smith.”
Marsh says he needs to start standing up at No.6.
“My bowling is just a bonus,” Marsh told the Herald Sun .
“I just want to do everything I can for the team to win. If that means getting my first hundred, that will be great. I feel that I’m not far away.”
Western Australia’s coach Justin Langer is also mentoring Marsh on the art of making big scores.
Former Test spinner Bryce McGain says Marsh is capable of being a world-class batsman and damaging pace bowler.
“I think he will be a terrific player along the lines of Jacques Kallis,” McGain said.
